questions.question: A video production company needs to store raw 4K footage that will be frequently accessed and edited over the next month, then archived for potential future use. Which storage strategy would be most cost-effective?
options: Store everything on high-capacity SSDs permanently
Use SSDs for active editing, then migrate to HDDs for archival
Use optical media for both active work and archival
Store everything on HDDs from the beginning
questions.explanation: SSDs provide the fast access speeds needed for 4K video editing, but HDDs offer much lower cost per GB for long-term archival storage where access speed is less critical.

questions.question: Why do SSDs typically have better performance than HDDs in laptop computers, especially when multitasking?
options: SSDs have larger storage capacities than HDDs
SSDs have no moving parts, eliminating seek time and mechanical delays
SSDs use less electrical power than HDDs
SSDs have better error correction algorithms
questions.explanation: SSDs use flash memory with no moving parts, allowing instant access to any location. HDDs must physically move read/write heads, creating delays especially when accessing multiple files simultaneously.

questions.question: A photographer wants to distribute a portfolio of high-resolution images to potential clients. The storage medium should be inexpensive, widely compatible, and tamper-evident. Which option best meets these requirements?
options: USB flash drives
Blu-ray discs
External HDDs
SD cards
questions.explanation: Optical media like Blu-ray discs are read-only when burned, making them tamper-evident. They're inexpensive to produce in quantity and have universal compatibility with most computers.

questions.question: What is the primary reason why magnetic storage devices can lose data when exposed to strong magnetic fields, while SSDs are unaffected?
options: Magnetic devices use older, less reliable technology
Magnetic devices store data as magnetized particles that can be reoriented
SSDs have built-in magnetic shielding
Magnetic devices have weaker error correction systems
questions.explanation: Magnetic storage encodes data by magnetizing tiny areas of the storage medium. External magnetic fields can alter these magnetic orientations, corrupting data. SSDs store data as electrical charges in flash memory cells, unaffected by magnetism.

questions.question: A research facility needs to store critical experimental data for 50+ years while maintaining data integrity. Environmental conditions may vary, and the storage medium should not require power. Which technology would be most appropriate?
options: Enterprise-grade SSDs in climate-controlled storage
High-quality optical discs with proper handling
RAID array of magnetic hard drives
Cloud storage with multiple redundant copies
questions.explanation: High-quality optical discs (like archival-grade Blu-ray) can last decades without power, are resistant to environmental changes, and won't degrade from magnetic fields. SSDs can lose data without power over long periods, and HDDs have mechanical components that degrade.
